title: BAA1028 - My reflection
text:
I must say, this has been an incredibly insightful module. It is like nothing I ever dreamed I would be doing at any point in life, so it is a major achievement for me to be able to say that I have produced my own website.
This journey has not come without its challenges. Learning to read HTML and CSS was not an easy feat for me. Additionally, it required me to become very familiar with the lecture material. It took a lot of study and concentration in lectures and by myself. In fact, there was a period where I was a few lectures behind, having not even been able to properly commit my changes to GitHub, which meant that my website remained bare for far longer than was acceptable. However, sitting down with my lecturer (thank you Damien) aided greatly in getting me back on track, which allowed me to catch up on past lectures and really begin to style my website. This meeting provided the ground work for the website that I have been able to submit.
I have found that producing a webpage such as this one requires a lot of trial and error. It takes patience and persistency to find the outcomes that you want. However, the results are more than rewarding.
From partaking in this module and completing this assignment, I have improved my web development skills, coding skills,
Special thanks to Damien Dupre, for allowing

title: New Enterprise Development
text:
In this module, we were tasked (as groups of 5) to generate an idea for a fully-fledged, profitable business. It took place over the course of 8 months, in which we were required to complete a preliminary business plan, Feasfibility Study, Marketing Video & campaign and a pitch to a group of esteemed entrepreneurs.
Our idea? We formulated a plan to produce an inventory management software targeted at small businesses.

title: Business Strategy
text:
Over the course of my final year, this module has been full of interesting learning curves.
My favourite project was the written group project, where myself and my team conducted a strategic review for Keogh‚Äôs Farms, a well-known Irish crisps company.

title: Daniel Odunsi
text:
I‚Äôm Daniel Odunsi, a final-year Business Studies student at Dublin City University (DCU) specialising in Data Analytics. My passions include business strategy, data-driven decision-making, public speaking, marketing and fitness.
I‚Äôve gained hands-on experience through internships at Novo Nordisk, Cantor Fitzgerald, and Ernst & Young, where I contributed to financial reporting, client services, and corporate strategy. These experiences, combined with my coursework in Business Processes & Lean Thinking and Financial Theory, have sharpened my analytical and problem-solving abilities.
Beyond academics, I take pride in leadership and community engagement. As Vice Chairman of DCU Boxing Club, I oversee club operations, events, and outreach, helping to foster a dynamic and inclusive environment.
I have broad technical proficiencies. This includes but is not limited to MS Office Suite, Python, and website design. My communication skills and compentency in Spanish allow me to communicate effectively in diverse settings.
Whether I‚Äôm optimising operations, crafting innovative solutions, or even creating a signature cocktail (see ‚ÄòThe Odunsi‚Äôüçπ), I bring creativity, dedication, and a results-driven approach to everything I do.
Enjoy my journey! üöÄ

title: Hobbies
text: Boxing, bartending and football are near and dear to my heart.

title: Hobbies
text:
Boxingü•ä
My roles as Public Relations Officer and later Vice Chairman of DCU Boxing Club have presented me with a host of interesting challenges and opportunities for creativity.
I was the first person in the club‚Äôs history to produce club tracksuits, which are now open for order for members of the club.
With the help of my teammates, I produced a ‚ÄòTechnique Tuesday‚Äô series, in which I teach beginners the fundamental principals of boxing.
I have also competed in multiple boxing events, representing DCU against other boxing clubs.

title: Machine Learning & Advanced Python
text:
In this module, I was given the task of using Known Machine Learning models to predict a set of outcomes of my choosing.
I chose to use a set of algorithms to classify good wine and bad wine, based on a variety of wine features.
My chosen algorithms were Logistic Regression, Random Forest Classifier and Gradient Boosting Classifier.
After choosing my dataset and 3 models, I got to work, tuning the hyperparameters and improving the learning accuracy, little by little.
I reached a peak accuracy of 64% using the Random Forest Classifier, concluding that I needed more data, more variables and a more powerful computer to detect all of the relationships between the features that affect wine quality.
Here is the list of features I used, complete with their correlation to the target variable, Wine Quality:









Check out the code I used for this classification task on Google Collab.
